subject: Real Estate
title: Why Buildings Depreciate but Land Doesn't
description: A 1-minute de-risking session on Why Buildings Depreciate but Land Doesn't.

hook.text: A new roof lasts 25 years. Plumbing lasts 50. Foundations crack. Every building is slowly falling apart.

buildup.text: The IRS lets owners depreciate residential buildings over 27.5 years, reducing taxable income each year.

discovery.text: But the land underneath doesn't wear out. It's exempt from depreciation â€” and it usually goes up.

twist.text: Savvy investors maximize the building-to-land ratio at purchase to claim bigger tax deductions.

climax.text: Depreciation is real estate's hidden tax advantage. The building decays on paper while the land gains value.

punchline.text: The tax code pays you for a building that's aging.

quiz.question: Why is land exempt from depreciation?
